docs.lead_paragraph: Marilyn B. Tavenner, administrator of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, helped oversee the rollout of changes in the health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare's top administrator unexpectedly resigned Friday, becoming the latest casualty in the turmoil over the president's health care law, which is still struggling for acceptance even as millions benefit from expanded coverage.

headline.main: Medicare Chief Steps Down, Ran Health Care Rollout
headline.print_headline: Medicare Chief Steps Down, Ran Health Care Rollout

docs.snippet: Medicare's top administrator unexpectedly resigned Friday, becoming the latest casualty in the turmoil over the president's health care law, which is still struggling for acceptance even as millions benefit from expanded coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: The courts did not grant Chatto Realuyo a divorce when it allowed her to end her marriage, 10 years after her husband moved out. They can't. They best they can do is say the marriage never happened.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled Thursday that the state must recognize hundreds of same-sex marriages performed during a brief window when they were allowed last year.

headline.main: Michigan: 300 Same-Sex Marriages Are Ruled Valid Pending Appeal
headline.print_headline: Michigan: 300 Same-Sex Marriages Are Ruled Valid Pending Appeal

docs.abstract: Federal Judge Mark Goldsmith orders Michigan to recognize hundreds of same-sex marriages that were conducted during brief window, following 2004 referendum allowing the marriages, before appeals court suspended decision.
docs.snippet: A federal judge ruled Thursday that the state must recognize hundreds of same-sex marriages performed during a brief window when they were allowed last year.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Gov. Rick Perry prepares to leave office and contemplates another run for the White House, his record in Texas will be closely scrutinized for what it says about him and the priorities he set.

headline.main: Perry Exits Texas Stage Making a Case for His Past, and His Future
headline.print_headline: Perry Exits Texas Stage Making a Case for His Past, and His Future

docs.abstract: Texas Gov Rick Perry makes farewell speech to state lawmakers as he prepares to leave office, emphasizing his successful 14-year tenure and paving way for possible 2016 presidential run; is departing under cloud of abuse of office charges.
docs.snippet: As Gov. Rick Perry prepares to leave office and contemplates another run for the White House, his record in Texas will be closely scrutinized for what it says about him and the priorities he set.

docs.lead_paragraph: With safety issues growing after the terrorist attacks in Paris, the French economy struggling and an open invitation from Israel to relocate, French-Israeli Jews in Netanya await new arrivals.

headline.main: For Jews From France, a Sociable Landing Spot in Israel
headline.print_headline: For Jews From France, a Sociable Landing Spot in Israel

docs.abstract: Netanya Journal; Israeli city Netanya has long been magnet for French-Jewish immigrants and after terrorist attacks in Paris, it is gearing up for greater than usual influx.
docs.snippet: With safety issues growing after the terrorist attacks in Paris, the French economy struggling and an open invitation from Israel to relocate, French-Israeli Jews in Netanya await new arrivals.

docs.lead_paragraph: If wage and health insurance issues are not resolved, more than 1,200 workers and drivers at the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market in the Bronx could go on strike as early as Sunday afternoon.

docs.lead_paragraph: Texas Governor Rick Perry gave his last major speech as leader of the country's second most populous state on Thursday, extolling a record of job creation and economic growth that has made him a possible 2016 Republican presidential contender.

headline.main: In Swan-Song Speech as Governor, Texas' Perry Touts Record
headline.print_headline: In Swan-Song Speech as Governor, Texas' Perry Touts Record

docs.lead_paragraph: On the day before the nation's high court could decide whether to take up Michigan's same-sex marriage case, a federal judge ruled that the state must recognize hundreds of such unions performed during a brief window when they were allowed last year.
